You missed a chance to add one more physiological phenomenon having to do with human vision -- motion camouflage.   As you demonstrated, the subjects were very good at following movement that travelled 90 degrees across their field of vision (i.e. tracking the girl friend walking and following the accelerating ball).  We humans are very poor at detecting motion parallel with our line of sight, when an object is coming straight at us.  We misjudge object distance and speed of approach quite often.  This is also called the SMIDSY effect (Sorry Mate I Didn't See You). It's true; Look it up.  SMIDSY is the leading cause of motorcycle accidents involving cars that pull out in front of the motorcyclist at the last minute, caused by the car driver at first failing to register the motorcycle against the visual "noise" of the background (as they scan for relative motion which you illustrated in the lion animation) and then panic stopping when the motorcycle looms into view.

I am thinking about another hypothesis for that: Maybe its related with the relative distance to the eyes of the observator at the begining of the motion.

-At first the ball travels "slow" and it is easy to follow. Because it is right in front of you the angle the eyes has to follow is wide.

-But when the ball is travelling faster... you can follow the distance it moves in a shorter time more or less with the same effort because the angle it travels is much less open.
In this way our brain measures speed asking itself how difficult it is to follow it in every moment. Like it is the same effort your brain senses the same speed.

A good way to falsify all this pobably wrong stuff would be doing the same experiment you did but dropping the ball higher relative to the witness and farther.

One of the ways to test vision in an uncooperative or cognitively impaired patient is to use a length of tape with vertical lines spaced regularly every centimeter along it's length. You hold the tape in front of the person's eyes, and pull the tape laterally across the visual field so the vertical lines move laterally in the person's visual field. This creates an effect similar to what you see when you're in a car looking out the side window, watching the trees move across  your visual field. While pulling the tape, you look closely at the subject's eyes for saccadic motion, an involuntary jerky lateral motion that is only present if the person can see. This test works even in infants, it's a very reliable sign that cannot be suppressed.

If your brain is trying to scan a scene it will jump from spot to spot- using saccades.  If you are tracking an object (or even tracking an imaginary object), your eyes can use smooth pursuit. If you spin long enough and stop, your eyes will involuntarily jump side-to-side for a while, and you'll perceive that everything is still spinning.

Apparently the brain doesn't percieve the blurs, and instead fills this part of the perception timeline with the next image it re-focusses on. So I guess your different capabilities horizontally and vertically are due to this.

We are effectively blind 40 or so minutes a day because of a process called saccadic masking. When are pupil "jumps" to another place, we are blind because our brain doesn't like rapid, blurry changes in vision. So, when we scan a fixed position, as we are moving (when you make the effort), you should see a tinge of darkness. That's you blind with your eyes open. Our brains hate us!

Close your eyes tight and nod your head slowly. you'll notice that your eyes have the tendancy to follow smoothly as if your looking at something still. This mechanism is used to help your eyes lock on to something while your moving. By sensing the motion of the head in the cochlea, you brain can tell you eyes where to move next to stay locked on target.
